БЛАГОПОЖЕЛАНИЯ МИРЯНАМ ПРИ ВЗЯТИИ ДАНЫ 
 
 
 ВАРИАНТ 1 
 Abhivādana-sīlissa—Niccaṁ vuḍḍhāpacāyino; 
 
 Постоянно выражая почтение нравственности и тем кого следует почитать 
 
 Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti—Āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṁ balaṁ. 
 
 Пусть увеличиваются четыре дхаммы: долголетие, успех, благополучие, здоровье 
 
 Ayu raro ge sampatti, 
 
 Желаю вам долголетия и отсутствия болезней. 
 
 Sage sampatti me vacha, 
 
 Пусть у тебя будет перерождение на небесах. 
 
 Ato nibbana sampatti, 
 Imina te samijjhatu. 
 
 Пусть однажды ты достигнешь Ниббаны! 
 
 
 Комментарий: 
 
 Однажды жили вместе два подвижника и практиковали аскетизм. Позже один из них вернулся к мирской жизни и женился. Когда у него и его жены родился сын, они отвели мальчика к другому подвижнику. Он сказал: «Живите долго!» родителям, но ребенку ничего не сказал. Родители были удивлены и спросили его, почему он это сделал. Подвижник сказал, что своими силами видел, что мальчик умрет еще через семь дней. Он послал их увидеть Будду, который мог знать, как предотвратить его смерть. Когда они подошли к Будде, он снова сказал: «Живите долго!» только родителям и ничего сыну. Чтобы предотвратить свою смерть, он велел родителям построить у их дома беседку и посадить в нее ребенка на кушетку. Затем он послал нескольких монахов повторять тексты для защиты. Многие боги и другие небесные существа пришли в павильон и присутствовали на нем. На седьмой день прибыл сам Будда. Затем в павильон пришел злой демон и стал у входа. Он ждал возможности напасть на мальчика. Но поскольку вокруг было так много могущественных существ, он не мог приблизиться к нему. Пение продолжалось всю ночь, а утром демону пришлось уйти. Маленького ребенка удалось спасти. 
 Затем он выразил свое почтение Будде, который сказал ему: «Живи долго! Прошло много лет и мальчик вырос. Однажды он пришел к Будде и спросил его, как обрести долголетие. n 
 Будда ответил этим стихом, сказав, что те, кто уважает людей с добродетельным характером и оказывает почтение тем, кто достоин почтения, обретут не только долголетие, но также красоту, счастье и силу. 
 
 


 KARANIA METTA SUTTA
 

Karaṇīyamatthakusalena, yanta santaṃ padaṃ abhisamecca;
 

This is what one should do who is skilled in good things and wants to achieve a peaceful state:
 

Sakko ujū ca suhujū [sūjū (sī.)] ca, sūvaco cassa mudu anatimānī.
 

Let him be able, direct and honest, meek, gentle and not proud,
 

Santussako ca subharo ca, appakicco ca sallahukavutti;
 

satisfied and unburdensome, with few responsibilities, content with little,
 

Santindriyo ca nipako ca, appagabbho kulesvananugiddho.
 

with calm perception abilities, reasonable, humble, and not fawning over families.
 

Na ca khuddamācare kiñci, yena viññū pare upavadeyyuṃ;
 

And let him not do the slightest thing that the wise would condemn.
 

Sukhino va khemino hontu, sabbasattā [sabbe sattā (sī. syā.)] bhavantu sukhitattā.
 

[And let him think:] Joyful and safe, may all beings be joyful in heart.
 

Ye keci pāṇabhūtatthi, tasā vā thāvarā vanavasesā;
 

Whatever the creatures, fragile or strong, without exception,
 

Dīghā vā ye va mahantā [mahanta (?)], majjhimā rassakā aṇukathūlā.
 

long, large, medium, small, small, thick,
 

Diṭṭhā vā ye va adiṭṭhā [adiṭṭha (?)], ye va [ye ca (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.)] dūre vasanti avidūre;
 

visible and invisible, living near and far,
 

Bhūtā va sambhavesī va [bhūtā vā sambhavesī vā (syā. kaṃ. pī. ka.)], sabbasattā bhavantu sukhitattā.
 

those who have come into the world and strive for manifestation: may all beings be joyful in heart.
 

Na paro paraṃ nikubbetha, nātimaññetha katthaci na kañci [naṃ kañci (sī. pī.), naṃ kiñci (syā.), na kiñci (ka.)] ;
 

Let no one upset another or despise anyone anywhere,
 

Byārosanā paṭighasaññā, nāññamaññassa dukkhamiccheyya.
 

and let no one wish another to suffer because of anger or an unpleasant impression.
 

Mātā yathā niyaṃ puttamāyusā ekaputtamanurakkhe;
 

As a mother, at the cost of her life, is ready to protect her child, her only child,
 

Evampi sabbabhūtesu, mānasaṃ bhāvaye aparimāṇaṃ.
 

so without restrictions to all beings he should develop this thought.
 

Mettañca sabbalokasmi, mānasaṃ bhāvaye aparimāṇaṃ;
 

For the whole world, let it develop the boundless thought of friendliness:
 

Uddhaṃ adho ca tiriyañca, asambādhaṃ averamasapattaṃ.
 

Up, down, and in between, without obstruction, malevolence, or foe.
 

Tiṭṭhaṃ caraṃ nisinno va, sayāno yāvatāssa vitamiddho [vigatamiddo (bahūsu)] ;
 

Standing, walking, sitting or lying down while not drowsy
 

Etaṃ satiṃ adhiṭṭheyya, brahmametaṃ vihāramidhamāhu.
 

Let him strive for this remembrance. It is spoken of as being in the state of brahma [straight] here
 

Diṭṭhiñca anupagamma, sīlavā dassanena sampanno;
 

Not confused with views, moral, he has insight,
 

Kāmesu vinaya gedhaṃ, na hi jātuggabbhaseyya punaretīti.
 

With the elimination of greed for sensual pleasures, he will never again be in the womb.
 

Mettasuttaṃ aṭṭhamaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.

 Tatiyampi

 Tatiyampi...

 Yamahaṃ vadāmi taṃ vadetha 

 what I say, then repeat 

 The candidate responds: 
 

 āma bhante! 

 Yes venerable 
 

 The candidate declares lines of respect. 
 

 Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambhuddhassa(x3) 
 

 After that, the mentor declares the lines of refuge with the ending in M, the kadidat repeats loudly and clearly: 
 

 Buddham, saraṇam, gacchāmi. 

 Dhammam, saraṇam, gacchāmi. 

 Saṇgham, saraṇam, gacchāmi. 

 Dutiyampi... 

 Tatiyampi... 
 

 After that, the mentor declares the lines of refuge with the ending in ṃ, the kadidat repeats loudly and clearly: 
 

 Buddhaṃ, saraṇaṃ, gacchāmi. 

 Dhammaṃ, saraṇaṃ, gacchāmi. 

 Saṇghaṃ, saraṇaṃ, gacchāmi. 

 Dutiyampi... 

 Tatiyampi... 
 

 Note. There is no semantic difference in the translation. The formula of refuge can be pronounced in any language if it is accepted by a layman. If a monk, then it should be pronounced only in the Pali language. Because this is an official action in the produced within the framework of the Wine Pitaka. Therefore, all sounds should be pronounced as close as possible to the original. The pronunciation of the Refuge is duplicated in case of incorrect pronunciation. The pronunciation at the end of the "am" is called Makaranta sarana gamane. And with the ending on "an" Niggahitānta sarana gamana. 
 

 After, the Mentor pronounces the end of the refuge: Sarana gamana sampunnam! 

 The candidate replies: Ama bhante!

 75 Sekhiya (rules for training) 
 

 The term in Pali literally means to train in. 
 

 There are 75 rules in this section of the Vinaya, which are divided into four categories: 
 

 1. etiquette of wearing robes and etiquette of behavior in a populated area; 

 2. etiquette in accepting and eating food from alms; 
 etiquette when teaching someone the Dhamma; 

 3. etiquette in relieving need. 
 
 The sum of these rules is the person of samaner and bhikkhu,
 and hence the appearance of the Sangha as a whole. 
 

 There are stories of how Bhante Sariputta was inspired by the manners of bhante Assaji and decided to join the community, as well as how King Ashoka converted to Buddhism under the impression of the manners of the young samanera.

 upasampada 
 Stanzas for the ceremony of becoming a Bhikkhu Rules of patimokkha ABOUT THE RULES OF PATIMOKKHA THE SYSTEM OF PUNISHMENTS PROVIDED FOR BY THE RULES OF PATIMOKKHA PARAJIKA 1
 If any monk participating in the training and lifestyle of monks, without refusing to study, without openly declaring his weakness, commits sexual intercourse with a woman or with a female animal, such a monk has been defeated and is no longer a member of the sangha. 
 The word "patimokkha" usually refers to a set of rules of conduct for Buddhist monks, established, according to Buddhist tradition, by the Buddha himself. These rules applied to almost all aspects of monastic life, according to these rules, all local Buddhist monastic communities functioned. The etymology of the word "patimokkha" (sancr. "pratimoksha") is not entirely clear. According to Mahavagga 2.3.4., this means the beginning, the head of all qualities. This term is used not only as the name of a set of rules of monastic behavior, but also the name of a sermon in which the Buddha outlined the basic principles common to the teachings of all Buddhas:"not doing all kinds of evil, doing all kinds of good, and purifying one`s own heart: this is the message of all the Buddhas" (Dhammapada, 183) 
 

In the early years of the Buddha s activity, there was no need to formulate any disciplinary rules. All the monks who followed him – the community of nuns did not exist then – were people of high personal achievements, those who succeeded in destroying all or many mental defilements. They knew the Buddhas teachings well and behaved accordingly. The canon tells how venerable Sariputta, one of the main disciples of the Buddha, asked the Buddha early enough to establish a Patimokkha, or set of rules. This set of rules could ensure the long life of the Buddhas teachings, just as the thread that binds together flower ornaments ensures that the flowers are not scattered by the wind. The Buddha replied that the time for such a code had not yet come, since even the most backward members of the community at that time already had the first experience of approaching the goal. Only when mental defilements (asava) make themselves felt in the community, there will be a need for the rules of Patimokkha. 
 

As time passed, the conditions that allowed mental pollution to enter the community began to appear. In the Bhaddali Sutta (M. 67), the Buddha lists five such conditions: 

"Bhaddali: "Why is it, dear sir, there were few rules of conduct before, and the number of monks who were established in the knowledge of Awakening was large? And why now, when there are many rules of conduct, fewer monks are confirmed in the knowledge of Awakening?" (Bhaddali, who did not want to live by disciplinary rules, suggests that an increase in the number of rules is the reason that fewer monks achieve Awakening. The Buddha, however, offers another explanation.)
Buddha: "So it is, Bhaddali. When living beings began to degenerate and the true Dharma began to disappear, many disciplinary rules appeared, and the number of monks who had established themselves in the knowledge of Awakening became small. The teacher (i.e., the Buddha himself) did not establish rules of conduct until conditions arose that contributed to the rise of mental pollution in the community. But when such conditions arose, the Teacher established rules of conduct as a means of countering such conditions. .. These conditions did not arise until the community became large. But when the community became large, conditions were created that contributed to the rise of mental pollution in the community. …When the community began to possess large material resources, ... a high status in society, ... a large body of teaching (texts), ... when the community had existed for a long time, ... then conditions were created that contributed to the rise of mental pollution in the community."
Thus, the rules themselves were not the cause of the degeneration of the community, and the conditions conducive to the rise of mental pollution were not in themselves pollution. Rather, the complication of the life of the community provided an opportunity for the monks to act on the basis of their pollution, and the rules – although they could not prevent any of these conditions – had to be complicated accordingly.
When establishing the rules of conduct, the Buddha justified the need for this with ten reasons: for the perfection of the sangha, for peace in the sangha, for abstinence from shamelessness, for the convenience of bhikkhus of good behavior, for the suppression of defilements related to the past life, for the prevention of defilements related to the future life, for raising faith in non-believers, for the growth of believers, for affirmations of the true dharma and for the education of students .
These causes fall into three types. The first two are external: to ensure peace and correct behavior within the sangha proper and to educate and protect the faith among lay followers of Buddhism. The third type of reasons are internal: to help control and prevent mental contamination within each individual monk. This last division quickly becomes the main one for anyone who seriously tries to follow the rules, as they help to develop mindfulness and concentration when performing any actions – those qualities that are necessary when training consciousness (mind).
The Buddha did not establish the whole set of rules at the same time. On the contrary, he formulated the rules one by one, in response to individual specific events. In the canon, all the cases about which a particular rule was formulated have been preserved, and often knowledge of these "origin stories" can help in understanding the meaning of a particular rule. For example, the history of the origin of the rule prohibiting sexually directed affectionate behavior between monks and women shows that the Buddha did not consider women as something unclean. On the contrary, this rule comes from the case when a monk gently touched the wife of a brahmin who came to visit his home, and the Buddha wanted the women to feel safe when coming to the monastery, knowing that no one would molest them.
Over time, the number of rules grew, and several followers of the Buddha, led by the pious Upali, collected the main rules into a complete set - the Patimokkha Sutta – which contained 227 rules. The Patimokkha sutta, as we know it now, is included in the text called the Vibhanga Sutta. It presents each rule preceding its origin story. It is followed by an explanation of what changes took place in this rule (if any) before it was fixed in its final form. The rule is then analyzed by its constituent elements to show how the factors of effort, object of action, perception, intention and result mitigate or do not mitigate the punishment prescribed by this rule. The discussion ends with a list of circumstances in which this action is not considered a violation, despite the rule.
The minor rules, which numbered several hundred, were collected into chapters distributed on topics called Khandaks. The Khandakas themselves are also divided into two parts: Mahavagga, or the Big Chapter, and Chulavagga, or the Smaller Chapter. Historians estimate that Vibhanga and Khandaki acquired their final form no later than the 2nd century BC. A little later, a Parivara was added to them – a text reviewing and systematizing the previous parts, and thus the canonical Vinaya pitaka was completed.
The system of punishments applied by the Buddha in his disciplinary rules was based on two principles. Firstly, the goal of Buddhist practice is primarily the development of the mind. Thus, the factors of intention and conscious perception of committed actions often determined whether a particular action was a violation of the rules. For example, the accidental killing of an animal, in terms of the action of the mind, is very different from intentional killing, and is not considered a violation of the rule prohibiting the killing of animals.
There are very few rules where the factors of intention and conscious perception do not play a role at all – such as the rule forbidding monks to drink alcohol – but they almost always deal with situations where an individual is expected to retain attentiveness and perceptual ability sufficiently to understand what he is going to do, and thus these rules also help train the mind.
In any case, the system of analyzing each violation in terms of effort, object, conscious perception, intention and result shows how firm adherence to the rules leads to the development of concentration and understanding. If a monk gets used to being aware of his actions in terms of these factors, he will develop mindfulness, an analytical approach to reality (the present) and perseverance. These are the first three factors of Enlightenment (awakening), forming the basis for the other three: joy, nobility, concentration and equanimity of the spirit.
The second principle used in certain punishments is based on the Buddha`s impressions of communication with Ananda, his main disciple. The Buddha became convinced that friendliness and sociability are extremely necessary in religious life. Anyone who approaches the Dharma seriously should be wise enough to understand that without the possibility of communication and learning from people who have already established themselves on the path, it is almost impossible to make progress on their own path. Thus, monks get used to appreciating their good reputation on the part of respected members of their group, and the whole system of punishments developed by the Buddha is built entirely on the impact on the status of the offender within the community. 
 
 
 Patimokkha classifies the rules of conduct into eight sections: 
 

1) parajika – defeat (exclusion from the community); 

2) sanghadisesa – requiring an initial (adi) and subsequent (sesa) community meeting; 

3) aniyata – indefinite (i.e. the result depends on the decision of the community); 

4) nissagia pachittia – requiring reckoning and recognition; 

5) pachittia – requiring recognition; 

6) patidesania – requiring recognition a certain form; 

7) sekhiya – instructions; 

8) adhikarana samatha – rules for the consideration of controversial issues arising in the community. 
 

Not all sections of Patimokkha are associated with certain types of punishments. Aniyatas rules give direction for solving uncertain cases. The rules of Sekhia relate primarily to the etiquette of behavior and simply state that one should behave in a certain way. The rules of the Adhikaran samatha are rather not rules, but principles according to which issues arising in the community should be resolved. 
 

The system of punishments prescribed by the rules consists of four main types, varying from final and unconditional expulsion from the sangha to a simple confession in the presence of another monk. 
 

A monk who has committed one of the four most serious offenses included in the section of the parajika is automatically considered deprived of the monastic title, even if no one knows about this offense. Therefore, there is no need to conduct any ceremony related to the deprivation of monastic dignity. The very act of committing a misdemeanor is an act of exclusion from the monastic community. A monk is considered to be excluded from the sangha completely and irrevocably, in this life he cannot re-enter the community. The same rules requiring exclusion from the community also applied to nuns. (there were four other rules of this category for nuns). In addition, nuns who returned to secular life as wives of householders were excluded from the community. 
 

If a monk violates one of the following important rules – the rules of the sanghadises, he is obliged to notify one of the monks and ask the community of at least four monks to impose a six-day period of punishment on him. During the punishment, the monk is deprived of his status and must comply with a number of restrictions, the main of which are the following: 

"he can`t live under the same roof with fully ordained monks."; 
 – he cannot leave the monastery without being accompanied by fully dedicated monks; 
 – every day he must inform all the monks in the monastery what violation he has committed and what punishment has been imposed on him. If there are visiting monks in the monastery, he is also obliged to inform them. 
 

After the term of punishment has ended, a monk can ask a community of at least twenty monks to rehabilitate him. After rehabilitation, he returns to his former status as a fully ordained monk of regular behavior. 
 

If a monk has been hiding for some time that he has violated one of the rules of the sanghadises, he must observe an additional probation period of the same duration as he hid his offense. Only after that he can ask for a six-day punishment and subsequent rehabilitation. 
 

Violations from the category of sanghadises are classified as severe – both because of their own seriousness, and because of the anxiety that the punishment and subsequent rehabilitation procedure brings to the community. 
 

The following type of punishment is imposed for violating the rules of nisaggia pachittia, which can be translated as "requiring reckoning and recognition." Each of the rules in this section is related to an item that the monk acquired or used incorrectly. Before publicly admitting his mistake, a monk must give this item "as payback" to his fellow monk or a group of monks. After a public confession, he is released from the offense. In most cases, the payment is symbolic – after his confession, the monk receives the item back, and only in three cases he gives the item away forever. 
 

A monk can make a confession of committing a violation in front of one or more monks or in front of the entire community. Only the violation of the rules regarding the receipt and use of money, as well as the receipt of an excessive bowl for collecting alms (NP No. 18, 19 and 22) requires mandatory recognition before the whole community. In the same three cases, incorrectly received or used items are not returned to the monk. In other cases, after receiving back his property, he must use it properly. 
 

Violations of this and the following two types are classified as mild. The guilt for the commission of the last two violations (pacchitia and patidesania) is removed through a simple confession to one monk or the entire community. The difference between these two sections is only that in the last section the form of recognition is fixed in the text of the rules of Patimokkha itself. 
 

In addition, there are also derivative punishments not specified in the rules of Patimokkha, but specified in the Vibhanga and in the comments. These derivative punishments deal with two kinds of cases: 
 

– a monk tries to perform an action specified in the rules, but for some reason the action does not reach its final completion (for example, a monk tries to kill someone, but this person does not die); 
 

– a monk performs an action not directly specified in the rules, but similar to that specified in the rules (for example, he strikes a layman – this case is not specified in the rules, but there is a clause when a monk strikes another monk). 
 

Such derivative punishments include thullachiya (in more serious cases) and dukkata (in less serious cases). The derivative punishment for incorrect speech also includes dubbhasita. The guilt for committing such derivative violations is removed through a simple confession. 
 

If these punishments do not correct the behavior of the violator, and he repeatedly violates the rules, the community can impose additional punishments on him. They may vary from the removal of certain privileges of seniority, expulsion from a separate community of monks or expulsion from the community as a whole. In all cases, the punishment is temporary, if the monk understands his mistakes and corrects his way of acting, the community returns him to his former status. The same temporary expulsion from the community occurs if the monk who committed the offense refuses to be punished. 
 

It should be noted that there is a lot of evidence in the canon that the Buddhas attitude to observing the rules of behavior was not too formal.

 GIRIMANANDA SUTTA 
 
 FOR GIRIMANANDA 
 
 Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme. Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca: 
 
 On one occasion the Blessed One was staying near Savatthi, in Jetas Grove, Anathapindikas monastery. And on that occasion Ven. Girimananda was diseased, in pain, severely ill. Then Ven. Ananda went to the Blessed One and, on arrival, having bowed down to him, sat to one side. As he was sitting there he said to the Blessed One: 
 
 – Āyasmā, bhante, girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yenāyasmā girimānando tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā ti. 
 
 – Lord, Ven. Girimananda is diseased, in pain, severely ill. It would be good if the Blessed One would visit Ven. Girimananda, out of sympathy for him. 
 
 Sace kho tvaṃ, ānanda, girimānandassa bhikkhuno dasa saññā bhāseyyāsi, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ girimānandassa bhikkhuno dasa saññā sutvā so ābādho ṭhānaso paṭippassambheyya. Katamā dasa? Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahāna·saññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, sabbasaṅkhāresu anicchāsaññā, ānāpānassati. 
 
 Ananda, if you go to the monk Girimananda and tell him ten perceptions, its possible that when he hears the ten perceptions his disease may be allayed. Which ten? The perception of inconstancy, the perception of not-self, the perception of unattractiveness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of abandoning, the perception of dispassion, the perception of cessation, the perception of distaste for every world, the perception of the undesirability of all fabrications, mindfulness of in out breathing. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, aniccasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati: rūpaṃ aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā, saññā aniccā, saṅkhārā aniccā, viññāṇaṃ aniccanti. Iti imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu aniccānupassī viharati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, aniccasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of inconstancy? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building — reflects thus: Form is inconstant, feeling is inconstant, perception is inconstant, fabrications are inconstant, consciousness is inconstant. Thus he remains focused on inconstancy with regard to the five clinging-aggregates. This, Ananda, is called the perception of inconstancy. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, anattasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati: cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, sotaṃ anattā, saddā anattā, ghānaṃ anattā, gandhā anattā, jivhā anattā, rasā anattā, kāyā anattā, phoṭṭhabbā anattā, mano anattā, dhammā anattāti. Iti imesu chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu anattānupassī viharati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, anattasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of not-self? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building — reflects thus: The eye is not-self, forms are not-self; the ear is not-self, sounds are not-self; the nose is not-self, aromas are not-self; the tongue is not-self, flavors are not-self; the body is not-self, tactile sensations are not-self; the intellect is not-self, ideas are not-self. Thus he remains focused on not-selfness with regard to the six inner and outer sense media. This is called the perception of not-self. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, asubhasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānāppakārassa asucino paccavekkhati: atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti. Iti imasmiṃ kāye asubhānupassī viharati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, asubhasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of unattractiveness? There is the case where a monk ponders this very body — from the soles of the feet on up, from the crown of the head on down, surrounded by skin, filled with all sorts of unclean things: There is in this body: hair of the head, hair of the body, nails, teeth, skin, muscle, tendons, bones, bone marrow, spleen, heart, liver, membranes, kidneys, lungs, large intestines, small intestines, gorge, feces, gall, phlegm, lymph, blood, sweat, fat, tears, oil, saliva, mucus, oil in the joints, urine. Thus he remains focused on unattractiveness with regard to this very body. This is called the perception of unattractiveness. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, ādīnavasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati: bahudukkho kho ayaṃ kāyo bahuādīnavo? Iti imasmiṃ kāye vividhā ābādhā uppajjanti, seyyathidaṃ: cakkhurogo sotarogo ghānarogo jivhārogo kāyarogo sīsarogo kaṇṇarogo mukharogo dantarogo oṭṭharogo kāso sāso pināso ḍāho jaro kucchirogo mucchā pakkhandikā sūlā visūcikā kuṭṭhaṃ gaṇḍo kilāso soso apamāro daddu kaṇḍu kacchu nakhasā vitacchikā lohitaṃ pittaṃ madhumeho aṃsā piḷakā bhagandalā pittasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā semhasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā vātasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā sannipātikā ābādhā utupariṇāmajā ābādhā visamaparihārajā ābādhā opakkamikā ābādhā kammavipākajā ābādhā sītaṃ uṇhaṃ jighacchā pipāsā uccāro passāvoti. Iti imasmiṃ kāye ādīnavānupassī viharati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ādīnavasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of drawbacks? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty dwelling — reflects thus: This body has many pains, many drawbacks. In this body many kinds of disease arise, such as: seeing-diseases, hearing-diseases, nose-diseases, tongue-diseases, body-diseases, head-diseases, ear-diseases, mouth-diseases, teeth-diseases, cough, asthma, catarrh, fever, aging, stomach-ache, fainting, dysentery, grippe, cholera, leprosy, boils, ringworm, tuberculosis, epilepsy, skin-disease, itch, scab, psoriasis, scabies, jaundice, diabetes, hemorrhoids, fistulas, ulcers; diseases arising from bile, from phlegm, from the wind-property, from combinations of bodily humors, from changes in the weather, from uneven care of the body, from attacks, from the result of kamma; cold, heat, hunger, thirst, defecation, urination. Thus he remains focused on drawbacks with regard to this body. This is called the perception of drawbacks. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, pahānasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannaṃ byāpāda·vitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, pahānasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of abandoning? There is the case where a monk does not tolerate an arisen thought of sensuality. He abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence. He does not tolerate an arisen thought of ill-will. He abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence. He does not tolerate an arisen thought of harmfulness. He abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence. He does not tolerate arisen evil, unskillful mental qualities. He abandons them, destroys them, dispels them, and wipes them out of existence. This is called the perception of abandoning. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, virāgasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati: etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhippaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nibbānanti. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, virāgasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of dispassion? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building — reflects thus: This is peace, this is exquisite — the stilling of all fabrications, the relinquishment of all acquisitions, the ending of craving, dispassion, Unbinding. This is called the perception of dispassion. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, nirodhasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati: etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhippaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo nirodho nibbānanti. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, nirodhasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of cessation? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building — reflects thus: This is peace, this is exquisite — the stilling of all fabrications, the relinquishment of all acquisitions, the ending of craving, cessation, Unbinding. This is called the perception of cessation. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu ye loke upādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā, te pajahanto viharati anupādiyanto. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of distaste for every world? There is the case where a monk abandoning any attachments, clingings, fixations of awareness, biases, or obsessions with regard to any world, refrains from them and does not get involved. This is called the perception of distaste for every world. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, sabbasaṅkhāresu anicchāsaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbasaṅkhāresu aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, sabbasaṅkhāresu anicchāsaññā. 
 
 And what is the perception of the undesirability of all fabrications? There is the case where a monk feels horrified, humiliated, and disgusted with all fabrications. This is called the perception of the undesirability of all fabrications. 
 
 Katamā cānanda, ānāpānassati? Idānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā. So satova assasati satova passasati. 
 
 And what is mindfulness of in and out breathing? There is the case where a monk — having gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building — sits down folding his legs crosswise, holding his body erect, and setting mindfulness to the fore. Always mindful, he breathes in; mindful he breathes out. 
 
 Dīghaṃ vā assasanto dīghaṃ assasāmīti pajānāti. Dīghaṃ vā passasanto dīghaṃ passasāmīti pajānāti. Rassaṃ vā assasanto rassaṃ assasāmīti pajānāti. Rassaṃ vā passasanto rassaṃ passasāmīti pajānāti. Sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmīti sikkhati. Sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmīti sikkhati. Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmīti sikkhati. Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmīti sikkhati. Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmīti sikkhati. 
 
 [i] Breathing in long, he discerns, I am breathing in long; or breathing out long, he discerns, I am breathing out long. [ii] Or breathing in short, he discerns, I am breathing in short; or breathing out short, he discerns, I am breathing out short. [iii] He trains himself, I will breathe in sensitive to the entire body. He trains himself, I will breathe out sensitive to the entire body. [iv] He trains himself, I will breathe in calming bodily fabrication. He trains himself, I will breathe out calming bodily fabrication. 
 
 Pītipaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmīti sikkhati. Pītipaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmīti sikkhati. Sukhapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmīti sikkhati. Sukhapaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmīti sikkhati. Cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmīti sikkhati. Cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmīti sikkhati. Passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmīti sikkhati. Passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmīti sikkhati. 
 
 [v] He trains himself to breathe in sensitive to rapture, and to breathe out sensitive to rapture. [vi] He trains himself to breathe in sensitive to pleasure, and to breathe out sensitive to pleasure. [vii] He trains himself to breathe in sensitive to mental processes, and to breathe out sensitive to mental processes. [viii] He trains himself to breathe in calming mental processes, and to breathe out calming mental processes. 
 
 Cittapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Cittapaṭisaṃvedī passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Abhippamodayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Abhippamodayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Samādahaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Samādahaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Vimocayaṃ cittaṃ assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Vimocayaṃ cittaṃ passasissāmī ti sikkhati. 
 
 [ix] He trains himself to breathe in sensitive to the mind, and to breathe out sensitive to the mind. [x] He trains himself to breathe in satisfying the mind, and to breathe out satisfying the mind. [xi] He trains himself to breathe in steadying the mind, and to breathe out steadying the mind. [xii] He trains himself to breathe in releasing the mind, and to breathe out releasing the mind. 
 
 Aniccānupassī assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Aniccānupassī passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Virāgānupassī assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Virāgānupassī passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Nirodhānupassī assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Nirodhānupassī passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Paṭinissaggānupassī assasissāmī ti sikkhati. Paṭinissaggānupassī passasissāmī ti sikkhati. Ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ānāpānassati. 
 
 [xiii] He trains himself to breathe in focusing on inconstancy, and to breathe out focusing on inconstancy. [xiv] He trains himself to breathe in focusing on dispassion,[1] and to breathe out focusing on dispassion. [xv] He trains himself to breathe in focusing on cessation, and to breathe out focusing on cessation. [xvi] He trains himself to breathe in focusing on relinquishment, and to breathe out focusing on relinquishment. This, Ananda, is called mindfulness of in andout breathing.

 This rule arose as a result of three different events: 
 
 The first event is related to the story of the young Sudinna Kalandaki. Who had sexual intercourse with his ex-wife. 
 
 The second event is related to the story of a monk who had sexual intercourse with a female monkey. 
 
 The third rule is associated with the Waji monks, who performed sexual acts without renouncing monasticism and without admitting their offense. 
 
 

Note: 
 

This rule arose 20 years after the launch of the Wheel of Dhamma 
 

There are six cases when parajika 1 is not performed: 
 
 1. Ajānantassa - A monk does not commit any crime if he is raped during deep sleep or in an unconscious state, since he is not aware of the sexual act. Moreover, the same applies when his penis is inserted into any of the 30 nimittas until he is aware of the act. 
 
 2. Asādiyantassa - When a monk does not agree. 
 
 3. Ummattakassa - When the monk has fallen into unconsciousness or is in a state of madness. 
 
 4. Khittacittassa - When a monk, being possessed by another spirit, can no longer control himself. 
 
 5. Vedanaṭṭa - A monk who suffers from severe pain and feels nothing but pain is also not guilty of committing sexual intercourse. 
 
 6. Ādikammikassa - The first criminal was acquitted of his misdeeds, since at that time there was no such training rule, called the first parajika. Therefore, the venerable Sudinna did not become a paredzic for his immoral act. But the monk who copulated with a female monkey and caused the first amendment to the rule was guilty of committing pārājikā. 
 

Factors 
 
 The following factors are necessary to find a monk guilty of committing the first parajika. 
 
 1. Sevanacittaṃ – intention (mind with intention) to perform sexual intercourse. 
 2. Maggena maggaṃ pavesanaṃ - insertion of the penis into one of the 30 organs (nimitta) 
 
 It should also be noted that a monk loses monasticism if he receives pleasure from intercourse during rape or when his penis is forcibly inserted into one of the organs without his consent. This factor is known as sādiyanaṃ. 
 

Citta and saññā 
 
 The first parajika is the crime of sacittaka. This means that a monk commits a crime for an intentional act, in this case, for sex. All sacittaka crimes are also called saññāvimokkha crimes. Therefore, the first parājika is the sassāvimokkha crime.

 Although for monks sexual behavior is a violation of pārājikā, for the laity it is not so unacceptable. If lay people lead a correct sex life, they will not be punished in any way. While the monk will be expelled from the sangha. Theft, in turn, is an inappropriate act for both laymen and monks. Being an honest person who abstains from stealing is a valuable element in the moral life of a bhikkhu. The word `thief` is considered obscene. It is extremely unsuitable for a monk. Therefore, a monk must be a pure person who will not take even a piece of grass that is not given to him, out of self-interest. This must be a person you can trust. While, taking even the grass weed from self-interest, a person becomes a thief. Of course, the Buddha did not consider such insignificant matters as objects of parajika, establishing the rule of the second parajika, he designated “pada” as the lower boundary, which is the lowest measure used by righteous rulers such as King Bimbisara, to punish thieves. This rule of adinnadana parrajika training is one of those which is very difficult to judge. It is also difficult to judge the measure of pada that is covered by the teaching rule adinnādāna pārājikā. It is also difficult to determine the value of some objects. Since there is twenty-five ways of committing theft, a bhikkhu who is not very well versed in the Vinaya, may unknowingly commit a parajika crime. Therefore bhikkhus should instill good crime knowledge base adinnadan pararajika. 
 
 25 types of theft 
 The disciplinary code specifies twenty-five ways of performing adinnādāna. If an item worth pādā is taken in any of the twenty-five ways, it will result in defeat. Knowledge of this rule will be complete only if these twenty-five methods, called avahāra, are known. Those who do not know them may fail unknowingly. 
 
 avahāra are divided into five groups 
 
 1. Nānābhaṇḍa pañcakā
 2. Ekabhaṇḍa pañcakā
 3. Sāhatthika pañcakā 
 4. Pubbapayoga pañcakā
 5. Theyyāvahāra pañcakā 
 
 Nānābaṇḍa pañcaka 
 As the name suggests, Nānābhaṇḍa pañcakā is fivefold. 
 1. Ādiyeyya – acquisition of someone else’s property through legal proceedings
 2. Hareyya - taking someone else`s thing with the intention of stealing, during delivery. 
 3. Avahareyya - acquisition through non-return of a thing taken for storage. 
 4. Iriyāpathaṃ vikopeyya - taking by changing the location of an object (so that the owner of the object thinks that it is not his.). 
 5. Ṭhānācāveyya – taking a thing from its place. 
 

Ekabaṇḍa pañcaka 
 (Nānābhaṇḍa pañcaka shows the acquisition of an object consciously or unconsciously through litigation and so on.) 
 
 The Ekabaṇḍa pañcaka shows the acquisition of animals or slaves belonging to others through such means as like a lawsuit. Making false claims for the purpose of acquiring a slave, elephant, horse, cattle or any other animal owned by another will result in committing the offense dukkaṭa. Raising doubts in the owner will result in the offense of tulakkai. Defeat will come when the owner loses hope. The remaining four methods of theft follow be considered as given in nānābaṇḍa pañcaka. 
 

Sāhatthika pañcaka 
 1. Sāhattikāvahāra – theft with one’s own hand
 2. Āṇattikāvahāra – theft by impulse, order (for both) 
 3. Nissaggiyāvahāra – theft by throwing away 
 4. Atthasādhakāvahāra – stealing at the first opportunity
 5. Dhuranikkhepāvahāra – loss of hope (by the owner). 
 

Pubbayoga pañcaka 
 1. Pubbayogāvahāra – theft by order
 2. Sahapayogāvahāra – land grab
 3. Saṃvidāvahāra – group theft
 4. Saṃketakammāvahāra – theft at a certain time
 5. Nimittakammāvahāra – theft by sign 
 

Theyyāvahāra pañcaka
 1. Theyyāvahāra – theft, scam, fake
 2. Pasayhāvahāra - robbery 
 3. Parikappāvahāra - if this happens, I will take it or take what I can carry
 4. Paṭicchannāvahāra – hiding an object
 5. Kusāvahāra - fraud 
 

Cases of violation 
 According to the value of the item 
 1. If an item worth five māsaka, which is equal to one pada or more, is stolen, then the bhikkhu has committed a crime involving the couple. ($50 or more)

 2. If an item worth 1 māsaka or more but less than five māsaka is stolen, the bhikkhu commits the crime of thullaccaya. (from 10 dollars) 
 
 3. If an item worth less than one masaka is stolen, the bhikkhu commits the crime of dukkata.(less than $10) 
 

Cases not violation 
 1. Sakasaññissa - A Bhikkhu who takes something belonging to another, thinking it is his, does not commit a crime on the basis of taking. What is taken must be given back (bhaṇḍadeyya). If not given, the bhikkhu will perform pārājikā if the value of the item is equal to pāda or more 
 
 2. Vissāsaggāhe (confidential) - if taken from the owner out of trust, no crime will be committed. 
 The Buddha spoke of five qualities that must be present in a person if he wants to take an object from the owner out of trust. 
 - Sandiṭṭho is a person with whom friendship was established at first sight. 
 - Sambhatto – with whom a strong friendship (brotherly relationship) was established 
 - Ālapito - a person who said: “If one of my things is pleasant, take it” - showing that asking permission is not necessary. 
 - Jīvati – he must be alive. Even with his last breath a person is considered alive. 
 - Gahite ca attamano - he rejoices at the taking. 
 Despite what was previously said about 5 qualities, three are enough to trust:
 I Sandiṭṭho, Jīvati, Gahite ca attamano 
 II Sambhatto, Jīvati, Gahite ca attamano 
 III Ālapito, Jīvati, Gahite ca attamano 
 Even if something is taken from a living person, and the owner is not happy that he was taken; out of a sense of confidence, it needs to be returned back. If a domestic or ascetic person owns the wealth of a deceased person, then it should be returned to him. The wealth belonging to those with unhappy minds should be returned directly to them. A person who first says or thinks, “You did well to take what belongs to me,” and then for some reason becomes angry, cannot ask for it back. Therefore, it is better to return or replace them,` then the one who took the thing must replace it. 
 
 3. Tāvakālikasaññissa – borrowing for a while with the thought “I will return it back” will not be considered a violation. 
 
 4. Petapariggahe - Buddha said that taking from non-human beings will not lead to parajika 
 
 5. Tiracchānagatapariggahe - Buddha said that taking creatures from animals will not lead to parajika 
 
 6. Paṃsukūlasaññissa – if you take things with the thought: “This thing is Paṃsukūla, no one’s” this is not a violation.

Khanda Paritta

This sutta is a teaching that the Buddha gave to the venerable Girimananda when he became seriously ill. From the earliest times, it came to be revered as a protective sermon — paritta — and was included in an ancient anthology of such sermons known as the Catubhāṇavāra.


The Girimananda Sutta is both a protective sutta and a profound teaching. The best protection for a person is to understand this sutta and practice in accordance with it. If such a practitioner falls ill, by listening to or reading this sutta, he will recall his practice. This will awaken and strengthen his bojjhaṅga — the factors of enlightenment — and the illness may weaken or even recede completely.


This sutta brings three kinds of well-being:


The first well-being is when a person understands it and practices in accordance with its meaning.

 The second well-being is when, during an illness, reading this sutta helps in the healing of that person.

 The third well-being is born from listening with saddhā — faith, trust, openness to the Teaching. From listening to the paritta with saddhā, a person can find relief from illness and even recover.
The Paritta combines admonition and verses of goodwill: four kinds of "snake kings" are listed (Virūpakkha, Erāpatha, Chabyāputta, Kaṇhāgotamaka) and an intention of goodwill is established towards all kinds of beings — footless, two-footed, four-footed, and many-footed — with the wish that no one should cause harm. 


In the tradition, it is believed that sincere mettā pacifies hostile forces and prevents misfortunes; in practice, however, the main protection is the stable development of mettā and mindfulness (sati) in daily life.

 Related story: The Elder Cakkhupāla 
 

Once there was a monk called Cakkhupāla who was determined not to lie down for the entire Rains Retreat. He developed an eye infection for which he need to lie down to take the medicine. But he refused to lie down, so the disease got worse and he became blind although he attained Arahantship, from his training.

The visiting monks noticed the quite a number of insects were killed on the elder’s walking meditation path and told they told Buddha. about it. The Buddha explained that the monk had killed them unintentionally and that he was an Arahant. (Intentional volition constitutes kamma whereas unintentional/involuntary/unconscious volition does not constitute kamma) 
 

The monks then asked Buddha why he became blind? Buddha narrated how in a previous life as a doctor, Cakkhupala treated a poor woman’s eyes.  The parable of Matthakundali 

 During his stay at the Jetavana monastery in Savatti, the Buddha recited this verse in connection with the story of the young brahmin Matthakundali. 

 Matthakundali was a young brahmin. His father Adinnapubbaka was very greedy and never gave alms. He even made gold jewelry for his son himself to save money for work. When his son got sick, he didn`t call a doctor until it was too late. When he realized that his son was dying, he took him out onto the veranda so that people who came to him would not see what he had in the house. That morning, the Buddha, coming out early from a deep meditation of compassion, saw in the Web of his Knowledge that Matthakundali was lying on the veranda. Therefore, when the Buddha came to Savatti for alms, he stopped at the house of the brahmin Adinnapubbaki. The Buddha directed a beam of light forward to attract the attention of a young man who was lying facing the house. The young man saw the Buddha, but since he was too weak, he could only mentally express his faith. But that was enough. When he died, filled with faith in the Buddha, he was reborn in the heavenly world of Tavatims. 

 From his heavenly home, the young Matthakundali, seeing his father grieving for him in the cemetery, appeared to him in his former form. He told his father that he had been reborn in the world of Tavatims and persuaded him to invite the Buddha for alms. 

 In the house of Adannapubbaki, the question was raised about whether it is possible to be reborn in the heavenly world by simply being devoted to the Buddha in thought, but not making alms and not observing moral principles. Then the Buddha made Matthakundali himself appear there; he appeared in heavenly attire and told about his rebirth in the world of Tavatims. Only then did the listeners become convinced that the son of the brahmin Adinnapubbaki received such honors simply by believing in the Buddha. 

 Then the Buddha recited this verse, Matthakundali and his father Adinnapubbaka reached Sotapatti Maga and Sotapatti Phala. Adinnapubbaka also donated almost all of his wealth to the cause of the Buddha`s Teachings.

 This rule arose as a result of two different events: 
 
 The first event is related to the story when the monks, after practicing meditation on the unattractiveness of the body, committed suicide by paying the man Megalandika to kill them. 
 
 The second event involves the monks from the group of six. They persuaded the sick husband of a laywoman to commit suicide so that he would stop suffering from his illness. 
 

Factors 
 
 For a manussaviggaha pārājikā crime to be committed, five factors must be present: 
 1. The creature to be killed is a human being. 
 2. Knowing that a creature is alive
 3. Intent to kill the creature
 4. Tactics, method, method of killing a creature
 5. This tactic, method, method led to the death of a person. 
 

METHODS OF KILLING 
 
 There are six ways in which murder can be committed: 
 
 1. SĀHATTHIKA-PAYOGA is the act of beating with one`s own body or sticks, swords, etc. connected to the body. This also includes glorifying death. 
 
 2. NISSAGGIYA-PAYOGA - this is the throwing of stones, the release of arrows, bullets, etc. with one`s own body or through an object connected to the body. 
 
 3. ĀṆATTIKA-PAYOGA is a command to another, saying: “Kill this person.” 
 
 4. THĀVARA-PAYOGA is digging holes, setting traps, spikes, etc. for the purpose of killing another. 
 
 5. VIJJĀMAYA-PAYOGA is the practice of witchcraft for the purpose of killing another. 
 
 6. IDDHIMAYA-PAYOGA is the use of the kamma-iddhi powers bestowed at birth to kill living beings. According to the literature, this ability is bestowed mainly on non-human beings, but some humans can also be endowed with it. 
 

CASES OF VIOLATION 
 
 1. A bhikkhu tries to kill a person. dukkaṭa for any efforts related to finding weapons and so on. If the person attacked suffers, the bhikkhu does thullaccaya. If a person dies, the bhikkhu performs pārājikā. 
 
 2. Bhikkhu tries to kill yakhs, petas, animals such as nagas in the form of humans. Trying to find weapons, etc., dukkaṭa. When non-human beings who are attacked suffer, the bhikkhu performs dukkaṭa. When these creatures die – thulaccaya. 
 
 3. A bhikkhu tries to kill an animal. All preliminary actions are dukkaṭa. If the attacked animal suffers - dukkaṭa. If the animal dies - pācittiya in accordance with the rule of teaching sañcicca. 
 
 
 

CASES OF NO VIOLATION 
 
 1. Asañcicca - If a bhikkhu performs an action without thinking that "as a result of this action a being may be killed", and yet the performance of this action actually results in the death of a person, parajika will not be performed. On one occasion, when one bhikkhu was arranging the seats in the hall, another raised a pestle and the first bhikkhu took one of them. The second pestle fell to the floor and hit the child on the head, resulting in death. The Buddha instructed that the bhikkhu did not commit any crime because he did not know that his act could kill a being, or did not know about it at all.

Ajānantassa - if a bhikkhu does not know that "this object, instrument or thing can cause the death of a being" and commits an act in which a person dies due to such object, instrument or thing, no crime will be committed. One day one bhikkhu served some of his food collected from the pindapata to another bhikkhu. Poison was mixed into the food, and the bhikkhu who donated the food did not know about it. The bhikkhu who ate it died. When the Buddha inquired, the donor bhikkhu stated that he did not know that poison had been mixed into the food. Therefore the bhikkhu is not guilty.

One day, a barren woman asked a bhikkhu for medicine to become pregnant. The bhikkhu gave the medicine that led to death. Since the bhikkhu had no intention of killing the woman, no crime will be committed.

 This rule arose as a result of two different events: 
 
 The first event involves monks who decide to praise each other as if they have superhuman abilities. They did this so that during a bad harvest, the laity would give them more food. 
 
 The second event involved monks who overestimated their abilities and said that they had achieved something that they had not actually achieved. When these monks realized that they were mistaken, they declared it. 
 
 

FACTORS 
 
 For uttarimanusadhamma pararajika to occur, five elements must be fulfilled. 
 
 1. Not possessing any of the higher human states 
 
 2. Claiming superior human qualities that a person does not actually possess, with the base intention of gaining fame and gain 
 
 3. Direct statement without subtext 
 
 4. A creature said to be human 
 
 5. Know right away, not later 
 

CASES OF VIOLATIONS 
 
 The following are instances of violations associated with this training rule. 
 
 1. If someone directly says that he has higher human states, which he actually does not possess, and the person hearing this immediately thinks: “This bhikkhu claims to have acquired jhana, says that he is a supreme or noble being.” etc., then the crime pārājikā is committed. 
 
 This can happen as described below. Even if the one who hears does not know about jhana from the point of view of exclusivity or the study of dhamma, but only knows the words jhana and vimokha, and understands it as “This bhikkhu can obviously enter the state of jhana, he obviously achieves vimokha.” etc., the bhikkhu will still be pārājikā. 
 
 Here`s how to express this idea. 
 
 A knowingly false statement: “I have reached the first (second/third/fourth) jhana (or level of phala, etc.)” will lead to pārājikā. 
 
 A deliberately false statement “I have reached the first (second/third/fourth) jhana (or the level of phala, etc.)” will lead to pārājikā. 
 
 Knowingly false statement "I will reach the first second/third/fourth) jhāna (or phalā level, etc.)" will lead to pārājikā. 
 
 Knowingly false statement "I regularly achieve the first (second/third/fourth) jhāna (or level of phalā, etc.)" will result in pārājikā. 
 
 A deliberately false statement “I have mastered the first (second/third/fourth) jhana (or the level of phala, etc.)” will lead to “parajika”. 
 
 A deliberately false statement, “I have fully comprehended the first (second/third/fourth) jhana (or level of phala, etc.)” will lead to pārājikā. 
 
 If the listener does not immediately understand the meaning of what was said, he will suspect: “What is he saying?” etc. or finds out about it much later by asking, then the bhikkhu will commit the crime of thullaccaya. For bhikkhus, pārājikā will not apply. 
 
 If it is indirectly mentioned: “He who lives in your temple obtains jhana,” etc., and the listener immediately understands this, then the bhikkhu commits the crime of tulacchaya. According to Kaṅkhāvitaraṇī Abhinavaṭīkā, since a bhikkhu does not directly say: “I have acquired jhāna,” etc., he is not a pārājikā. 
 
 If what is said indirectly is not immediately understood by the listener, the bhikkhu will commit the crime of dukkatta. The Abhinavaṭīkā notes that the crime of dukkaṭa will be committed because an attempt has been made to deceive others by making false statements. 
 
 If, with the intention of gaining respect from others, a bhikkhu walks and behaves in a certain way or lives in a forest monastery, then the crime of dukkatta is committed. 
 
 Wanting to mention his highest human state, a person mistakenly mentions another highest human state instead, knowing that this is a false statement, and if the listener instantly understands this, then there will be parājika. For example, wanting to say, “I attain the first jhana,” if one actually says, “I attain the second jhana,” and if the listener instantly understands this, then the bhikkhu pārājikā. 
 
 CASES OF NO VIOLATIONS 
 
 The following are the illegal actions associated with the fourth rule of parajik. 
 
 1. Adhimanena - if you mention the highest states of a person without actually possessing them, from adhimana, there will be no violation. 
 
 2. Anullapanādhippāyassa - If one speaks without the intention of hinting to others about the superior human condition that one possesses, no crime will be committed. For example, when a Dhamma matter regarding an arahant is explained, and if a person says, "Consider that I am an arahant. Then those who scold me in this way will be guilty of aryopavada," etc. With the intention of continuing to explain a Dhamma matter, there is no violation .

RULE DESCRIPTION 
 
 The wealth of a monk is spiritual values such as sīla, patience, compassion, samādhi, abhiññā, wisdom, etc. A monk who is truly spiritual will be revered not only by lay people but also by other monks. Therefore, if Monax says he has great achievements and qualities that he really does not have, this is a deception done in hopes of gaining respect. Of these achievements, jhāna, abhiññā, magga and phala are the most highly valued. They are called the highest states of man. A person who has achieved such states is a superior personality. He will be worthy of worship by all beings of the world, including all gods. A monk who claims to have achieved the highest human states when he has not is trying to gain the respect of other people through cunning and deception. Therefore, claiming to have the highest human states when in fact this is not the case is a grave mistake, which can lead to denying the status of the highest initiation proclaimed by the Buddha. 
 
 TRANSLATION OF SOME TERMS 
 
 1. Yo pana bhikkhu anabhijānaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ attūpanāyikaṃ alamariyañāṇadassanaṃ samudācareyya `Iti jānāmi, iti passāmī`ti. 
 
 In the phrase "anabhijānaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ alamariyañāṇadassanaṃ attupanāyikaṃ katvā `iti jānāmi, iti passāmī`ti samudācareyya", the part "alamariyañāṇadassanaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ anabhi jānaṃ" means knowing that one does not possess any higher human states. The highest human states are jhāna, abhiññā, magga and phala. Since these are a series of pure states of wisdom capable of eradicating vices in the forms of suppression (vikkhambhana), eradication (samuccheda) and pacification (paṭippassaddhi), they are called (alamariyañāṇadassana). 
 
 The remaining words should be interpreted as follows: 
 
 "taṃ asantaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ anabhijānaṃ attūpaṇāyikaṃ katvā `iti jānāmi iti passamī`ti samudacareyya." Knowing that he does not possess any higher human states which have not been achieved by himself, if he implies that he possesses them or has achieved certain states, and proclaims “I know, I have seen,” and directly makes such false statements (lies) , this will lead to pārājikā. 
 
 AÑÑATRA ADHIMĀNĀ 
 
 The phrase "aññatra adhimānā" means that the crime of pārājikā can only be committed if a person mentions higher human states that he does not possess, without deluding himself about his achievement. If a bhikkhu, without having received magga or phala, affirms in his mind the thought: “I have achieved,” this is known as having adhimana. A bhikkhu who has adhimana says that he has reached the highest human states only because he has a wrong idea of himself, and not with the intention of deceiving others. Therefore, a bhikkhu who claims to have the highest human states because of adhimāna, when in fact he does not, does not commit any crime according to this rule of teaching. This crime can only be committed if a person knowingly makes a false claim that he possesses higher human states which he does not actually possess. 
 
 ADHIMĀNĀ 
 
 (excessive confidence in one`s own achievements) 
 
 Even if jhana or magga-phala has not been achieved, some may have the misconception that it has been achieved. This is called adhimana. Such overconfidence does not arise in immoral people who do not expect to achieve jhana or any other higher state of man. It also does not arise in virtuous people who do everything else except Samatha and Vipassana meditation. Meditators who follow pure virtue and meditate with great determination can sometimes develop such a wrong perception. Noble beings never experience adhimana. Therefore a person who has attained the state of sotāpanna can never think that he has attained the state of sakadāgāmī, anāgāmī or arahant. It is noted that those who have developed samatha or vipassana can develop adhimana regarding the lowest path and fruition and will never develop the delusion of thinking that they have become arahants, while those who have developed both samatha and vipassana can to experience adhimanu thinking that one has attained arhatship. The commentaries note that some Mahatharas in the early periods lived with adhimana for years, thinking that they had achieved arhatship. Since declaring higher human states due to adhimana does not involve deception, it will not lead to the commission of any crime. 
 

FIVE GREAT THIEVES (MAHĀCORA) 
 
 The primary reason for the announcement of the fourth rule of parajika is the monks of Vaggumuda declaring that they had achieved the highest human states when in fact they had not, and obtaining benefits and treatment from people by deceiving them by claiming so. The Buddha sharply despised this disgusting act in his sermons and said that there are five great thieves in this world: 
 
 1. The first great thief is a bhikkhu who gathers many monks and creates a large group of which he becomes the leader; and, using such a group and thanks toits numbers, receives benefits and treatment from laymen and monks. 
 
 2. A bhikkhu who studies the Dhamma preached by the Buddha preaches it to the masses. In this case, people find it pleasant and say with reverence, “Venerable sir, your preaching of the Dhamma is admirable. From whom did you learn this Dhamma.” The bhikkhu refrains from mentioning his teacher and replies: “And who teaches us,” implying that the Dhamma was found by himself. Such a bhikkhu is considered the second great thief of sasana. 
 
 3. The third great thief is a bhikkhu who steals another`s values (such as morality) by accusing a noble being or bhikkhu kalyāṇa puthujjana, who is pure in virtue and celibate, of committing the first crime of pārājikā - sexual intercourse. 
 
 4. A monk who gives away property that cannot be distributed among the people (avebhaṅgiya garu bhaṇḍa), such as paddy fields, gardens, furniture, steel containers, etc., belonging to the Saṅgha, with the intention of making the lay people happy, is the fourth great thief. A bhikkhu who entertains lay people using objects belonging to the Saṅgha performs kuladūsana dukkaṭa. It will be suitable for pabbājanīyakamma.. This is the act of expelling a monk or nun from the temple. When objects belonging to the Saṅgha are given away against the will of the monk, if the monk has authority among the Saṅgha, the crime of thullaccaya is committed. If this is done out of secrecy (self-interest and the desire to hide), then pārājikā is committed. 
 
 5. A bhikkhu who deceives the world by saying that he has the highest human qualities when in fact he does not possess them is the greatest thief of words, including the deities.
